I don't know much about Tobe Hooper, or why he gets his name in the title, but maybe he shouldn't have bothered. Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern times. The success of George A. Romero’s first entry into that particular camp called ‘Night Of The Living Dead’ spawned nine additional movies, as well as several popular theatrical sequels by other filmmakers. With popularity apparent, studios wanted in on this zombie action flick cash cow.

Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it pleases - "waiting my turn" -, while the Dutch continue with their long-standing tradition of queueing (the 10-minute extended coffee breaks are just another reinforcement), accept whatever crummy spot they can beg or borrow without first having 'rights' on it, and tolerate

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to Polish director Agnieszka Holland’s style.
Holland initially appears to be positioning this movie as an attack against British colonialism; indeed Finn’s family arrives shortly after the ship which has brought them from England and is bombed by Maori tribe members who believe their passengers are invincible warriors.

After watching this movie, I couldn't help but notice the parallels between it and another film called America 3000. Both were very bad mid 1980's scifi movies that feature a girl who fantasizes about robots (like Wall-e) making her life better. In both cases she risks everything to escape into a Utopia like one ruled by robots.
